Uniaxial Neo-Hookean Demo#

This tutorial demonstrates how to use lib-ela to model the uniaxial deformation of a Neo-Hookean material, a classic example in nonlinear elasticity.

Learning Objectives

By the end of this tutorial, you will be able to:

  • Instantiate a Neo-Hookean material from lib-ela

  • Compute the Cauchy stress as the uniaxial stretch λ increases

  • Plot the stress–stretch curve and mark the tangent modulus

  • Interpret the mechanical response of the material

Prerequisites

  • Basic knowledge of Python programming

  • Familiarity with Jupyter Notebooks (recommended)

  • Basic understanding of continuum mechanics concepts

Installation

pip install lib-ela matplotlib numpy

Step 1: Set Up the Environment

Note

This tutorial assumes you have a working Python environment. We recommend using Jupyter Lab or Google Colab for an interactive experience.

Let’s start by importing the required libraries and setting up our material model:

1import numpy as np
2import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
3from libela.hyperelastic import NeoHookean
4
5# Material properties (SI units: Pa, -)
6E, nu = 10e6, 0.45  # Young's modulus and Poisson's ratio
7
8# Create the Neo-Hookean material model
9mat = NeoHookean(E=E, nu=nu)

Step 2: Generate a Stretch Range

Next, we’ll create a range of uniaxial stretches to analyze the material’s response:

1lam = np.linspace(1.00, 2.00, 61)          # 0 % … 100 % engineering strain
2sigma = mat.stress(
3    lam,
4    protocol="uniaxial",
5    stress_type="cauchy",                  # returns array
6)

Step 3: Plot and Annotate

Now, let’s visualize the stress–stretch curve and mark the tangent modulus:

 1plt.figure(figsize=(6, 4))
 2plt.plot(lam, sigma / 1e6, label="Neo-Hookean")
 3plt.xlabel("Stretch λ (–)")
 4plt.ylabel("Cauchy stress (MPa)")
 5plt.title("Uniaxial tension")
 6plt.grid(True)
 7
 8# tangent modulus at λ = 1.2
 9idx = np.searchsorted(lam, 1.2)
10plt.scatter(lam[idx], sigma[idx] / 1e6, c="k")
11plt.text(
12    lam[idx] + 0.02,
13    sigma[idx] / 1e6,
14    f"Tangent ≈ {mat.tangent(lam[idx]):.1f} MPa",
15    va="center",
16)
17
18plt.legend()
19plt.show()

Step 4: Compare with a Nearly-Incompressible Variant

Finally, let’s compare the compressible Neo-Hookean material with a nearly-incompressible variant:

 1from libela.hyperelastic import NearlyIncompressibleMixin
 2
 3class NH_NI(NearlyIncompressibleMixin, NeoHookean):
 4    """Neo-Hookean with volumetric penalty."""
 5
 6mat_ni = NH_NI(E=E, nu=0.49, K=8 * E)      # large bulk modulus
 7
 8sigma_ni = mat_ni.stress(lam, protocol="uniaxial", stress_type="cauchy")
 9
10plt.figure(figsize=(6, 4))
11plt.plot(lam, sigma / 1e6,     label="Compressible (ν = 0.45)")
12plt.plot(lam, sigma_ni / 1e6, label="Nearly incompressible (ν = 0.49)")
13plt.xlabel("Stretch λ (–)")
14plt.ylabel("σ (MPa)")
15plt.legend()
16plt.grid(True)
17plt.show()
